questions.question_text: What is the Declaration of Independence in the context of United States history?

options.A: A document adopted July 4, 1776, by the Constitutional Convention creating a framework of self-governance for the thirteen colonies under British oversight.
options.B: A document adopted July 4, 1776, by the First Continental Congress establishing a trade alliance between the thirteen colonies and Great Britain.
options.C: A document adopted July 4, 1776, by the Second Continental Congress declaring the thirteen colonies independent from Great Britain.
options.D: A document adopted October 19, 1781, by the Second Continental Congress outlining terms of peace between the thirteen colonies and the British Crown.

questions.question_text: What was the American Civil War?

options.A: A war from 1854 to 1861 between Northern and Southern militias over tariff disputes and trade policy in the border states.
options.B: A war from 1861 to 1865 between the United States and a coalition of Native American nations resisting federal western expansion.
options.C: A war from 1861 to 1865 between the United States and Great Britain over disputed territorial claims along the western frontier.
options.D: A war from 1861 to 1865 between the United States and eleven seceding Southern states that formed the Confederate States of America.

questions.question_text: What is the Constitution of the United States?

options.A: The supreme law of the nation, drafted at the 1781 Confederation Congress in New York, organizing the federal government across seven articles.
options.B: The supreme law of the nation, drafted at the 1787 Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, organizing the federal government across seven articles.
options.C: The original governing charter of the nation, drafted at the 1787 Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, organizing the federal government as a single legislature.
options.D: The supreme law of the nation, drafted at the 1776 Continental Congress in Philadelphia, organizing the federal government across twelve articles.

questions.question_text: What was the abolitionist movement in the United States?

options.A: A movement in the 18th and 19th centuries that sought to gradually relocate enslaved people to West African colonies rather than grant freedom.
options.B: A movement in the 18th and 19th centuries that sought to end slavery and emancipate all enslaved people in America.
options.C: A movement in the 18th and 19th centuries that sought to end British colonial taxation and establish free trade among American states.
options.D: A movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries that sought to end child labor and establish compulsory public education.

questions.question_text: What event directly caused the United States to enter World War II?

options.A: Germany's bombing of American merchant ships in the North Atlantic on December 7, 1941, prompting Congress to declare war.
options.B: Japan's surprise attack on the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on December 7, 1941, prompting Congress to declare war.
options.C: Germany's submarine attack on the USS Reuben James off Iceland on October 31, 1941, prompting Congress to declare war immediately.
options.D: Japan's invasion of the Philippine Islands on December 7, 1941, prompting Congress to declare war after a week of debate.

questions.question_text: What was the Great Depression in the United States?

options.A: A severe agricultural crisis triggered by the 1929 Dust Bowl drought, causing mass rural displacement and crop failure throughout the 1930s.
options.B: A severe economic crisis triggered by the 1929 stock market crash, causing mass unemployment and poverty throughout the 1930s.
options.C: A severe banking crisis triggered by the 1929 stock market crash, affecting only Wall Street investors while industrial employment remained stable.
options.D: A severe economic crisis triggered by the 1919 postwar recession, causing mass unemployment and currency collapse throughout the 1920s.

questions.question_text: What was the Civil Rights Movement in the United States?

options.A: A movement mainly during the 1950s and 1960s in which immigrant communities fought to end restrictive quotas and win citizenship rights.
options.B: A movement mainly during the 1930s and 1940s in which labor unions fought to end economic exploitation and win fair wage protections.
options.C: A movement mainly during the 1950s and 1960s in which Black Americans fought to end racial segregation and win equal legal rights.
options.D: A movement mainly during the 1970s and 1980s in which Black Americans fought to end housing discrimination and win federal reparations.

questions.question_text: What was the American Revolution?

options.A: A colonial revolt from 1765 to 1775 in which thirteen British colonies won independence from France and formed the United States.
options.B: A colonial revolt from 1775 to 1783 in which thirteen British colonies won independence from Great Britain and formed the United States.
options.C: A colonial revolt from 1775 to 1783 in which eight British colonies won independence while five others negotiated continued dominion status.
options.D: A colonial revolt from 1775 to 1783 in which thirteen British colonies won self-governance from Great Britain while remaining in the Commonwealth.

questions.question_text: What was the Emancipation Proclamation?

options.A: An executive order issued by President Lincoln on January 1, 1863, declaring enslaved people in Confederate states free and allowing Black military enlistment.
options.B: A constitutional amendment proposed by President Lincoln on January 1, 1863, permanently abolishing slavery throughout the entire United States and its territories.
options.C: An executive order issued by President Lincoln on January 1, 1863, declaring all enslaved people in every state free and granting them immediate citizenship.
options.D: An executive order issued by President Andrew Johnson on January 1, 1863, declaring enslaved people in Confederate states free and redistributing land.

questions.question_text: What was the Moon landing in the context of United States history?

options.A: The Apollo 11 mission on July 20, 1969, when John Glenn and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to orbit and photograph the Moon.
options.B: The Gemini 11 mission on July 20, 1967, when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the Moon.
options.C: The Apollo 11 mission on July 20, 1969, when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the Moon.
options.D: The Apollo 13 mission on July 20, 1969, when Neil Armstrong and Michael Collins became the first humans to walk on the Moon.

questions.question_text: How many hijackers carried out the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks against the United States?

options.A: Twelve hijackers affiliated with al-Qaeda seized two commercial airliners.
options.B: Fifteen hijackers affiliated with al-Qaeda seized three commercial airliners.
options.C: Nineteen hijackers affiliated with al-Qaeda seized four commercial airliners.
options.D: Twenty-one hijackers affiliated with Hezbollah seized four commercial airliners.

questions.question_text: Which president authorized the Louisiana Purchase, and from which country was the territory acquired?

options.A: President John Adams acquired the territory from France for approximately twenty million dollars in 1800.
options.B: President Thomas Jefferson acquired the territory from Britain for approximately ten million dollars in 1801.
options.C: President James Madison acquired the territory from Spain for approximately fifteen million dollars in 1803.
options.D: President Thomas Jefferson acquired the territory from France for approximately fifteen million dollars in 1803.

questions.question_text: Who introduced the amendments that became the Bill of Rights, and when were they ratified?

options.A: Thomas Jefferson introduced them in Congress in 1790, and ten of the fifteen proposed amendments were ratified by December 1792.
options.B: Alexander Hamilton introduced them in Congress in 1788, and all twelve proposed amendments were ratified by December 1790.
options.C: George Washington introduced them in Congress in 1789, and eight of the twelve proposed amendments were ratified by December 1791.
options.D: James Madison introduced them in Congress in 1789, and ten of the twelve proposed amendments were ratified by December 1791.

questions.question_text: What informal political agreement ended the Reconstruction era in 1877?

options.A: The Wormley Agreement of 1878, in which Republicans ceded control of Congress to Democrats in exchange for ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment.
options.B: The Bargain of 1876, in which Democrats accepted Ulysses Grant for a third term in exchange for amnesty for former Confederate leaders.
options.C: The Compromise of 1877, in which Democrats accepted Rutherford B. Hayes as president in exchange for the withdrawal of federal troops from the South.
options.D: The Compromise of 1877, in which Republicans accepted Samuel Tilden as president in exchange for continued federal oversight of Southern elections.

questions.question_text: Which New Deal program established a federal corporation to provide flood control, electricity, and economic development to a major river basin?

options.A: The Tennessee Valley Authority, created in 1933, brought infrastructure, cheap electricity, and jobs to one of the nation's poorest regions.
options.B: The Civilian Conservation Corps, created in 1933, built dams and power stations along the Mississippi River to provide rural electrification.
options.C: The Rural Electrification Administration, created in 1935, built a network of federal dams along the Ohio River to supply power to Appalachian communities.
options.D: The Works Progress Administration, created in 1935, constructed hydroelectric plants across the Columbia River basin to stimulate regional growth.

questions.question_text: Who coined the phrase 'manifest destiny,' and in what context was it first used?

options.A: Senator Henry Clay coined it in 1844 in a congressional speech arguing for the annexation of Oregon Country.
options.B: Editor Horace Greeley coined it in 1843 in the New York Tribune arguing for settlement of the Great Plains.
options.C: President James K. Polk coined it in 1846 in his inaugural address arguing for war with Mexico.
options.D: Journalist John L. O'Sullivan coined it in 1845 in the United States Magazine and Democratic Review, arguing for the annexation of Texas.

questions.question_text: Which four constitutional amendments were ratified during the Progressive Era, and what did they collectively accomplish?

options.A: The 17th through 20th Amendments established direct election of senators, women's suffrage, prohibition, and a new presidential inauguration date.
options.B: The 16th through 19th Amendments established a federal income tax, direct election of senators, prohibition, and women's suffrage.
options.C: The 16th through 19th Amendments established a federal income tax, abolished poll taxes, imposed prohibition, and lowered the voting age.
options.D: The 13th through 16th Amendments abolished slavery, guaranteed equal protection, granted Black male suffrage, and established a federal income tax.

questions.question_text: What military alliance did the United States help establish in 1949 to counter Soviet expansion in Europe?

options.A: The Central Treaty Organization, whose founding treaty committed Western and Middle Eastern nations to mutual defense against communist aggression.
options.B: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, whose founding treaty declared that an attack on one member would be considered an attack on all.
options.C: The Western European Union, whose founding treaty bound European nations to joint military action without requiring American participation.
options.D: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, whose founding treaty pledged collective defense of democratic nations in the Pacific region.

questions.question_text: What congressional resolution gave President Johnson broad authority to escalate American military involvement in Vietnam?

options.A: The Pacific Defense Resolution, passed in January 1965 after a Viet Cong attack on the American embassy in Saigon.
options.B: The Indochina Security Resolution, passed in June 1964 after North Vietnamese forces crossed the demilitarized zone into South Vietnam.
options.C: The Southeast Asia Resolution, passed in March 1965 after the bombing of a US military base at Pleiku in South Vietnam.
options.D: The Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, passed in August 1964 after reported attacks on US destroyers off the coast of North Vietnam.

questions.question_text: From which literary work did the Gilded Age get its name?

options.A: Mark Twain and Charles Dudley Warner's 1873 satirical novel The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today, which mocked post-Civil War greed and corruption.
options.B: Mark Twain's 1884 novel Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, which critiqued Southern hypocrisy and racial injustice in antebellum America.
options.C: Upton Sinclair's 1906 novel The Jungle, which exposed unsanitary conditions in the meatpacking industry and political corruption in Chicago.
options.D: Henry Adams's 1880 novel Democracy: An American Novel, which satirized Washington political culture and the influence of money in government.

questions.question_text: Which two landmark programs were created by the Social Security Amendments of 1965 as part of Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society?

options.A: Medicare, providing health insurance for those aged 65 and over, and Medicaid, funding medical costs for low-income individuals.
options.B: Food Stamps, providing nutritional assistance for low-income households, and Job Corps, offering vocational training for unemployed youth.
options.C: Social Security Disability Insurance for injured workers and Supplemental Security Income funding living costs for low-income elderly.
options.D: Head Start, providing early childhood education for low-income families, and VISTA, sending volunteers to impoverished communities.

questions.question_text: What federal law, signed by President Andrew Jackson in 1830, authorized the forced relocation of Native Americans known as the Trail of Tears?

options.A: The Indian Removal Act, which authorized the president to negotiate removal treaties with Native American tribes east of the Mississippi.
options.B: The Indian Trade and Intercourse Act, which authorized the president to regulate commerce and restrict settlement on tribal lands.
options.C: The Indian Appropriations Act, which authorized the president to establish reservations and confine tribes to designated federal territories.
options.D: The Dawes Act, which authorized the president to survey and allot tribal lands to individual Native American households.

questions.question_text: What was the 'Saturday Night Massacre' during the Watergate scandal?

options.A: Nixon's firing of Senate Watergate committee chairman Sam Ervin in October 1973, prompting the resignations of Vice President Agnew and Solicitor General Bork.
options.B: Nixon's firing of special prosecutor Archibald Cox in October 1973, prompting the resignations of Attorney General Richardson and Deputy Attorney General Ruckelshaus.
options.C: Nixon's dismissal of White House counsel John Dean in October 1973, prompting the resignations of Chief of Staff Haldeman and domestic advisor Ehrlichman.
options.D: Nixon's ordering the CIA to halt the FBI's Watergate investigation in October 1973, prompting the resignations of FBI Director Gray and Deputy Director Felt.

questions.question_text: Which amendment to the U.S. Constitution granted women the right to vote, and when was it ratified?

options.A: The Twentieth Amendment, ratified on January 23, 1933.
options.B: The Seventeenth Amendment, ratified on April 8, 1913.
options.C: The Nineteenth Amendment, ratified on August 18, 1920.
options.D: The Eighteenth Amendment, ratified on January 16, 1919.

questions.source_article: Women's suffrage in the United States
concepts_tested: women's suffrage in the United States

questions.question_text: What role did Samuel Slater play in launching the Industrial Revolution in the United States?

options.A: He invented the cotton gin in Georgia and built the first successful steam-powered cotton processing plant in Savannah, Georgia, in 1793.
options.B: He imported British iron smelting techniques to America and built the first successful coal-fired blast furnace in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, in 1793.
options.C: He brought British textile manufacturing knowledge to America and built the first successful water-powered cotton spinning mill in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, in 1793.
options.D: He adapted British railroad engineering for America and built the first successful steam-powered locomotive line in Baltimore, Maryland, in 1793.

concepts_tested: Industrial Revolution in the United States

questions.question_text: How did the Korean War begin, and what was the outcome when it ended in 1953?

options.A: North Korea invaded South Korea across the 37th parallel in August 1950; it ended with a 1953 ceasefire that ceded the northern provinces permanently to China.
options.B: North Korea invaded South Korea across the 38th parallel in June 1950; it ended with a 1953 armistice that left Korea divided near the same line.
options.C: China invaded South Korea across the Yalu River in June 1950; it ended with a 1953 armistice that created an independent buffer state between the two Koreas.
options.D: South Korea attacked North Korea across the 39th parallel in June 1950; it ended with a 1953 peace treaty that unified Korea under a democratic government.

questions.question_text: What were the key provisions of the Missouri Compromise of 1820, and what later legislation effectively repealed it?

options.A: It admitted Missouri as a slave state and Ohio as a free state, banning slavery in the Northwest Territory north of 35 degrees; the Wilmot Proviso of 1846 repealed it.
options.B: It admitted Missouri as a slave state and Vermont as a free state, banning slavery in all western territories north of 38 degrees; the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 repealed it.
options.C: It admitted Missouri as a free state and Kentucky as a slave state, banning slavery in Oregon Territory north of 40 degrees; the Compromise of 1850 repealed it.
options.D: It admitted Missouri as a slave state and Maine as a free state, banning slavery in Louisiana Purchase territory north of 36 degrees 30 minutes; the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 repealed it.

questions.question_text: In Dred Scott v. Sandford (1857), what did Chief Justice Roger B. Taney's majority opinion rule regarding African Americans and the Missouri Compromise?

options.A: That African Americans were not U.S. citizens but could petition state courts for freedom, and that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional because it violated the First Amendment's right to free assembly.
options.B: That African Americans were not U.S. citizens and could not sue in federal court, and that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional because it violated slaveholders' Fifth Amendment property rights.
options.C: That African Americans held limited citizenship with restricted legal standing, and that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional because it exceeded Congress's authority under the Commerce Clause.
options.D: That African Americans were U.S. citizens but lacked voting rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, and that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional because it violated the Tenth Amendment's reserved powers.

questions.question_text: What was the Omaha Platform of 1892, and what happened to the Populist Party after the 1896 presidential election?

options.A: It was the People's Party platform demanding gold standard restoration, trust regulation, and an eight-hour workday; the party collapsed after endorsing Greenback candidate James Weaver in 1896.
options.B: It was the People's Party platform demanding protective tariffs, national banking reform, and land grants for settlers; the party collapsed after endorsing Republican William McKinley in 1896.
options.C: It was the People's Party platform demanding currency inflation, abolition of the Senate, and public ownership of utilities; the party collapsed after endorsing Socialist Eugene Debs in 1896.
options.D: It was the People's Party platform demanding free silver coinage, railroad regulation, and a graduated income tax; the party collapsed after endorsing Democrat William Jennings Bryan in 1896.

questions.question_text: What did the Reconstruction Acts of 1867, passed by the Radical Republicans over President Johnson's veto, impose on the former Confederate states?

options.A: They divided the South into five military districts commanded by army generals and required states to ratify the Fourteenth Amendment and grant Black men the vote before readmission.
options.B: They divided the South into three civilian administrative zones overseen by federal judges and required states to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment and abolish debt peonage before readmission.
options.C: They divided the South into seven reconstruction territories governed by appointed governors and required states to ratify the Fifteenth Amendment and redistribute plantation land before readmission.
options.D: They divided the South into ten probationary counties supervised by Treasury agents and required states to ratify the Twelfth Amendment and establish integrated public schools before readmission.

questions.question_text: After the Spanish-American War of 1898, the Treaty of Paris required Spain to cede several overseas territories to the United States. Which of the following correctly lists territories acquired through that treaty?

options.A: The Philippines, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico were ceded by Spain under the Treaty of Paris of 1898.
options.B: Guam, Puerto Rico, and the Panama Canal Zone were ceded by Spain under the Treaty of Paris of 1898.
options.C: The Philippines, Guam, and Puerto Rico were ceded by Spain under the Treaty of Paris of 1898.
options.D: The Philippines, Guam, and Cuba were ceded by Spain under the Treaty of Paris of 1898.

questions.question_text: The Second Great Awakening fueled numerous antebellum reform movements. Which evangelist, famous for his revivals in western New York's "burned-over district," also denounced slavery from the pulpit and refused communion to slaveholders?

options.A: Charles Grandison Finney, who later taught at Oberlin College, which admitted students regardless of race or sex.
options.B: Theodore Dwight Weld, who later taught at Oberlin College, which admitted students regardless of race or sex.
options.C: Charles Grandison Finney, who later taught at Yale Divinity School, which admitted students regardless of race or sex.
options.D: Lyman Beecher, who later taught at Oberlin College, which admitted students regardless of race or sex.

questions.question_text: The Harlem Renaissance was also known by a name derived from a 1925 anthology edited by the first African American Rhodes Scholar. What was this anthology and who edited it?

options.A: "The New Negro," edited by Alain Locke, which gave the movement its alternate name, the New Negro Movement.
options.B: "The New Negro," edited by Langston Hughes, which gave the movement its alternate name, the New Negro Movement.
options.C: "The Weary Blues," edited by Alain Locke, which gave the movement its alternate name, the New Negro Movement.
options.D: "The New Negro," edited by W. E. B. Du Bois, which gave the movement its alternate name, the New Negro Movement.

questions.question_text: During the Army-McCarthy hearings of 1954, one exchange became iconic in discrediting Senator Joseph McCarthy on live television. Who delivered the famous rebuke, and what was its consequence for McCarthy?

options.A: CBS journalist Edward R. Murrow challenged McCarthy's cruelty; the Senate censured McCarthy in December 1954 by a vote of 67 to 22.
options.B: Army counsel Joseph Welch challenged McCarthy's cruelty; the Senate censured McCarthy in December 1954 by a vote of 67 to 22.
options.C: Army counsel Joseph Welch challenged McCarthy's cruelty; the Senate censured McCarthy in June 1954 by a vote of 67 to 22.
options.D: Army counsel Joseph Welch challenged McCarthy's cruelty; the Senate expelled McCarthy in December 1954 by a vote of 67 to 22.

questions.question_text: Senator Stephen Douglas's Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 applied the principle of popular sovereignty to new western territories. What earlier landmark compromise did this act effectively repeal, and what violent conflict resulted?

options.A: It repealed the Missouri Compromise's ban on slavery north of 36 degrees 30 minutes latitude, triggering the guerrilla conflict known as Border Ruffian Wars.
options.B: It repealed the Missouri Compromise's ban on slavery north of 36 degrees 30 minutes latitude, triggering the guerrilla conflict known as Bleeding Kansas.
options.C: It repealed the Compromise of 1850's ban on slavery north of 36 degrees 30 minutes latitude, triggering the guerrilla conflict known as Bleeding Kansas.
options.D: It repealed the Missouri Compromise's ban on slavery north of the Mason-Dixon Line, triggering the guerrilla conflict known as Bleeding Kansas.

questions.question_text: The US Cold War strategy of containment originated from a diplomat's analysis of Soviet behavior. In what form did George F. Kennan first articulate this strategy, and how was it later published for public audiences?

options.A: Kennan delivered a speech at the Council on Foreign Relations in February 1946, then published the strategy anonymously as "X" in Foreign Affairs in July 1947.
options.B: Kennan sent the "Long Telegram" from Moscow in February 1946, then published the strategy anonymously as "X" in Foreign Affairs in July 1947.
options.C: Kennan sent the "Long Telegram" from Moscow in February 1947, then published the strategy anonymously as "X" in Foreign Affairs in July 1948.
options.D: Kennan sent the "Long Telegram" from Moscow in February 1946, then published the strategy under his own name in Foreign Affairs in July 1947.

questions.question_text: Anti-Federalists opposed ratification of the Constitution partly because it lacked explicit protections for individual rights. How did Federalists initially respond to demands for a bill of rights, and how was the dispute ultimately resolved?

options.A: Federalists called a bill of rights unnecessary since state constitutions already protected rights; the compromise yielded the first twelve amendments, ratified in 1791.
options.B: Federalists called a bill of rights unnecessary since the government held only enumerated powers; the compromise yielded the first ten amendments, ratified in 1791.
options.C: Federalists called a bill of rights unnecessary since the government held only enumerated powers; the compromise yielded the first ten amendments, ratified in 1789.
options.D: Federalists called a bill of rights dangerous since it would limit federal authority; the compromise yielded the first ten amendments, ratified in 1791.

questions.question_text: After the Civil War, sharecropping became the dominant agricultural labor system across the South. How did the crop-lien system interact with sharecropping to perpetuate economic dependency among formerly enslaved people?

options.A: Sharecroppers pledged future crops as collateral for credit from merchants, trapping them in cycles of debt when harvest proceeds failed to cover advances.
options.B: Sharecroppers pledged future crops as collateral for credit from federal agencies, trapping them in cycles of debt when harvest proceeds failed to cover advances.
options.C: Sharecroppers pledged their land titles as collateral for credit from merchants, trapping them in cycles of debt when harvest proceeds failed to cover advances.
options.D: Sharecroppers pledged future crops as collateral for credit from merchants, but federal subsidies typically prevented them from falling into debt cycles.

questions.question_text: During the Nullification Crisis, South Carolina declared federal tariff acts unconstitutional within its borders. What specific document did Vice President John C. Calhoun anonymously author to provide the theoretical basis for nullification, and how did President Jackson ultimately resolve the crisis?

options.A: Calhoun's "South Carolina Exposition and Protest" opposed the Tariff of 1828; Jackson sent troops to Charleston and Congress repealed the tariff entirely in 1833.
options.B: Calhoun's "South Carolina Exposition and Protest" opposed the Tariff of 1828; Jackson issued a Nullification Proclamation and Congress enacted a compromise tariff in 1833.
options.C: Calhoun's "South Carolina Exposition and Protest" opposed the Tariff of 1832; Jackson issued a Nullification Proclamation and Congress enacted a compromise tariff in 1835.
options.D: Calhoun's "Virginia and Kentucky Resolutions" opposed the Tariff of 1828; Jackson issued a Nullification Proclamation and Congress enacted a compromise tariff in 1833.

questions.question_text: In the Bank War, President Andrew Jackson vetoed the recharter of the Second Bank of the United States in 1832 and then removed federal deposits. What did Jackson do with the withdrawn federal funds, and what major economic crisis followed the Bank's demise?

options.A: Jackson redistributed federal deposits to state-chartered "pet banks"; the removal of central banking regulation contributed to the Depression of 1836.
options.B: Jackson redistributed federal deposits to state-chartered "pet banks"; the removal of central banking regulation contributed to the Panic of 1839.
options.C: Jackson placed federal deposits in the US Treasury's independent sub-treasuries; the removal of central banking regulation contributed to the Panic of 1837.
options.D: Jackson redistributed federal deposits to state-chartered "pet banks"; the removal of central banking regulation contributed to the Panic of 1837.

concepts_tested: Second Bank of the United States

questions.question_text: The Compromise of 1850 replaced the Missouri Compromise's geographic line with a new principle for determining slavery's status in the Utah and New Mexico territories. What was this principle, and why did it prove so controversial?

options.A: Popular sovereignty, allowing territorial settlers to decide slavery's legality by vote, which reinforced the fixed geographic boundary that had maintained sectional balance since 1820.
options.B: Congressional arbitration, allowing each territorial legislature to petition Congress for a binding ruling on slavery, which undermined the fixed geographic boundary that had maintained sectional balance since 1820.
options.C: Judicial determination, allowing federal circuit courts to rule on slavery's legality in each territory, which undermined the fixed geographic boundary that had maintained sectional balance since 1820.
options.D: Popular sovereignty, allowing territorial settlers to decide slavery's legality by vote, which undermined the fixed geographic boundary that had maintained sectional balance since 1820.

questions.question_text: The Freedmen's Bureau was officially named the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands. Within which executive department was it placed in 1865, and why did this placement shape its enforcement capacity?

options.A: The War Department, which gave the Bureau access to military infrastructure and personnel for enforcement but also tied its authority to an institution expected to expand permanently after the Civil War.
options.B: The Treasury Department, which gave the Bureau access to financial infrastructure and personnel for enforcement but also tied its authority to an institution expected to demobilize after the Civil War.
options.C: The War Department, which gave the Bureau access to military infrastructure and personnel for enforcement but also tied its authority to an institution expected to demobilize after the Civil War.
options.D: The Interior Department, which gave the Bureau access to land-management infrastructure and personnel for enforcement but also tied its authority to an institution expected to demobilize after the Civil War.

questions.source_article: Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands

questions.question_text: During the XYZ Affair of 1797-1798, French agents demanded specific financial concessions before negotiations could begin with the American envoys. What were the two main financial demands, and what popular slogan did the American public adopt in response?

options.A: A \$12 million loan to France and a \$250,000 personal bribe to Foreign Minister Talleyrand. The public rallied around the slogan "Liberty or death in defense of American honor."
options.B: A \$12 million loan to France and a \$250,000 personal bribe to Foreign Minister Talleyrand. The public rallied around the slogan "No entangling alliances with foreign powers."
options.C: A \$6 million loan to France and a \$500,000 personal bribe to Foreign Minister Talleyrand. The public rallied around the slogan "Millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute."
options.D: A \$12 million loan to France and a \$250,000 personal bribe to Foreign Minister Talleyrand. The public rallied around the slogan "Millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute."

questions.question_text: Before President Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in June 1930, over one thousand economists petitioned him to veto the bill. What was the primary economic consequence they warned about, and how severely did it materialize?

options.A: They warned that retaliatory tariffs from trading partners would collapse international trade. U.S. imports from Europe fell from \$1.3 billion in 1929 to \$900 million by 1932, briefly slowing the Great Depression.
options.B: They warned that retaliatory tariffs from trading partners would collapse international trade. U.S. exports to Europe fell from \$1.3 billion in 1929 to \$390 million by 1932, but had little effect on the Great Depression.
options.C: They warned that domestic overproduction would collapse consumer prices. U.S. imports from Europe fell from \$1.3 billion in 1929 to \$390 million by 1932, deepening the Great Depression.
options.D: They warned that retaliatory tariffs from trading partners would collapse international trade. U.S. imports from Europe fell from \$1.3 billion in 1929 to \$390 million by 1932, deepening the Great Depression.

questions.question_text: In Muller v. Oregon (1908), the Supreme Court unanimously upheld a state law limiting women's workdays to ten hours, just three years after striking down a similar law for bakers in Lochner v. New York. How did Justice Brewer's opinion distinguish the two cases?

options.A: Brewer held that physical differences between the sexes justified sex-based labor regulation, explicitly overruling Lochner and establishing that all workers deserved maximum-hour protections regardless of sex.
options.B: Brewer held that physical differences between the sexes justified sex-based labor regulation, explicitly declining to overrule Lochner but carving out an exception based on women's distinct biological and social circumstances.
options.C: Brewer held that physical differences between the sexes justified sex-based labor regulation, explicitly declining to overrule Lochner but carving out an exception based on the Fourteenth Amendment's equal protection clause.
options.D: Brewer held that economic differences between laundry and bakery industries justified industry-based labor regulation, explicitly declining to overrule Lochner but carving out an exception based on workplace hazard levels.

questions.question_text: The Platt Amendment of 1901 effectively made Cuba a U.S. protectorate after the Spanish-American War. What specific military provision persisted even after the amendment's repeal in 1934, and what policy shift led to that repeal?

options.A: The lease of Guantanamo Bay as a U.S. naval base was retained under the 1934 Treaty of Relations, while the rest of the amendment was abrogated under Franklin Roosevelt's Dollar Diplomacy policy toward Latin America.
options.B: The lease of Guantanamo Bay as a U.S. naval base was retained under the 1934 Treaty of Relations, while the rest of the amendment was abrogated under Herbert Hoover's Good Neighbor policy toward Latin America.
options.C: The lease of Guantanamo Bay as a U.S. naval base was retained under the 1934 Treaty of Relations, while the rest of the amendment was abrogated under Franklin Roosevelt's Good Neighbor policy toward Latin America.
options.D: The right to intervene militarily in Cuban affairs was retained under the 1934 Treaty of Relations, while the rest of the amendment was abrogated under Franklin Roosevelt's Good Neighbor policy toward Latin America.

questions.question_text: In 1932, the Bonus Army of approximately 43,000 demonstrators, including 17,000 WWI veterans, marched on Washington to demand early payment of service bonus certificates. Who commanded the military force that dispersed the encampment, and what was the major political consequence?

options.A: Army Chief of Staff General Douglas MacArthur commanded infantry, cavalry, and six tanks to evict the veterans. The violent dispersal boosted Hoover's public image but he still lost narrowly to FDR in 1932.
options.B: Army Chief of Staff General Douglas MacArthur commanded infantry, cavalry, and six tanks to evict the veterans. The violent dispersal damaged Roosevelt's public image and contributed to his narrow victory over Hoover in 1932.
options.C: Army General Dwight Eisenhower commanded infantry, cavalry, and six tanks to evict the veterans. The violent dispersal damaged Hoover's public image and contributed to his landslide defeat by FDR in 1932.
options.D: Army Chief of Staff General Douglas MacArthur commanded infantry, cavalry, and six tanks to evict the veterans. The violent dispersal damaged Hoover's public image and contributed to his landslide defeat by FDR in 1932.

questions.question_text: The Credit Mobilier scandal, exposed by the New York Sun during the 1872 election, involved a construction company created by Union Pacific Railroad executives. What was the core fraudulent mechanism, and what was the most severe penalty Congress imposed on its own members?

options.A: Executives used Credit Mobilier to issue fraudulent stock directly to the federal Treasury, pocketing roughly \$44 million in excess charges. Congress censured Representatives Oakes Ames and James Brooks.
options.B: Executives used Credit Mobilier to bill the federally subsidized Union Pacific vastly inflated construction costs, pocketing roughly \$44 million in excess charges. Congress censured Representatives Oakes Ames and James Brooks.
options.C: Executives used Credit Mobilier to bill the federally subsidized Union Pacific vastly inflated construction costs, pocketing roughly \$44 million in excess charges. Congress expelled Representatives Oakes Ames and James Brooks.
options.D: Executives used Credit Mobilier to bill the federally subsidized Union Pacific vastly inflated construction costs, pocketing roughly \$12 million in excess charges. Congress censured Representatives Oakes Ames and James Brooks.

questions.question_text: The Pentagon Papers, a 47-volume classified Defense Department study leaked by Daniel Ellsberg in 1971, led to a landmark Supreme Court ruling. What did the Court decide in New York Times Co. v. United States, and by what margin?

options.A: In a 6-3 decision, the Court ruled that the government's attempt to impose prior restraint on publication was justified by national security, temporarily blocking the Times and Washington Post from publishing the documents.
options.B: In a 5-4 decision, the Court ruled that the government's attempt to impose prior restraint on publication violated the First Amendment, allowing the Times and Washington Post to continue publishing the documents.
options.C: In a 6-3 decision, the Court ruled that the government's attempt to impose prior restraint on publication violated the Fourth Amendment, allowing the Times and Washington Post to continue publishing the documents.
options.D: In a 6-3 decision, the Court ruled that the government's attempt to impose prior restraint on publication violated the First Amendment, allowing the Times and Washington Post to continue publishing the documents.

concepts_tested: New York Times Co. v. United States

questions.question_text: The War Powers Resolution of 1973 created a specific time limit on unauthorized presidential deployment of armed forces. What is the maximum duration before the president must withdraw troops absent congressional authorization, and how did this legislation become law?

options.A: Sixty days, extendable to ninety if the president certifies that troop safety requires additional withdrawal time. Congress enacted it by overriding President Ford's veto with a two-thirds vote in each chamber.
options.B: Sixty days, extendable to ninety if the president certifies that troop safety requires additional withdrawal time. Congress enacted it by overriding President Nixon's veto with a two-thirds vote in each chamber.
options.C: Sixty days, extendable to ninety if the president certifies that troop safety requires additional withdrawal time. Congress enacted it after President Nixon reluctantly signed it under political pressure from both chambers.
options.D: Ninety days, extendable to one hundred twenty if the president certifies that troop safety requires additional withdrawal time. Congress enacted it by overriding President Nixon's veto with a two-thirds vote in each chamber.
